posts._title: Edward Yang – Kong bu fen zi aka The Terrorizers (1986)
posts.title: Kong bu fen zi
posts.excerpt: Quote:The lives of anonymous strangers become intricately intertwined in this 1986 effort by late Taiwanese auteur Edward Yang. Following the sudden death of his superior, a doctor frames his colleague in order to succeed as the clinic’s director. The doctor’s writer wife, meanwhile, is experiencing a mid-life crisis, struggling to finish her next novel while …

posts._title: F.W. Murnau – Nosferatu, eine Symphonie des Grauens (1922)
posts.title: Nosferatu, eine Symphonie des Grauens
posts.excerpt: Quote: Based illegally on Bram Stoker’s Dracula, F. W. Murnau’s film is undeniably the best and probably the most faithful of the myriad of films based on the novel. Naively, the film’s producers attempted to circumvent the author’s estate’s copyright by changing the names and central location of the film. London became Wisborg, Count Dracula …

posts._title: Justin Benson & Aaron Moorhead – The Endless (2017)
posts.title: The Endless
posts.excerpt: Quote: This mind-bending thriller follows two brothers who receive a cryptic video message inspiring them to revisit the UFO death cult they escaped a decade earlier. Hoping to find the closure that they couldn’t as young men, they’re forced to reconsider the cult’s beliefs when confronted with unexplainable phenomena surrounding the camp. As the members …

posts.title: The Killing (1956)
posts.excerpt: Review: When it comes to addressing old films, there are two broad schools of thought: one is that they don’t make them like they use to and the other is that technology has improved the quality of films. While each side has its pros and cons what it often boils down to is citing examples. …

posts._title: Jean Rollin – La morte vivante aka The Living Dead Girl [Uncut] (1982)
posts.title: La morte vivante
posts.excerpt: Quote: Thought of by some as the last truly great film of Jean Rollin’s career, the 1982 feature La Morte Vivante (The Living Dead Girl) is a fascinating but flawed feature graced with two of the most unforgettable performances in all of Rollin’s canon. posts._title: Dag Yngvesson – Rated X: A Journey Through Porn (1999)
posts.title: Rated X: A Journey Through Porn
posts.excerpt: In this insiders look at life in the porn business, filmmaker Dag Yngvesson speaks with both naïve newcomers and seasoned skin-flick veterans to offer a revealing portrait of cinema’s most controversial cash cows. posts._title: Walerian Borowczyk – Interno di un convento aka Behind Convent Walls (1977)
posts.title: Interno di un convento
posts.excerpt: Before it became possible (in the late 19th and early 20th centuries) to imprison young heirs and heiresses in mental institutions in order to gain control of their inheritances, greedy families had for centuries “given” their daughters to convents without the girls’ consent. posts.title: Ladies of the Night
posts.excerpt: Quote: LUSH AND GOTHIC, RARELY HAS EROTICA IN FILM BEEN SO STUNNINGLY PRESENTED. Night is falling. A frightened Schoolgirl makes her way along the deserted cobbled street, glancing fearfully around her. She is being pursued, but by whom–or what? posts.title: Endless Waltz
